Buncombe! The Sunday, May 26, 2013 New York Times featured a long article (in the Business section) titled, “Breeding the Nutrition Out of Food.”
People prefer the new breeds of produce because of how they choose their fruits and vegetables. One, is size. Tiny wild strawberries are loaded with flavor, but commercial strawberries are gigantic in comparison and have less flavor and nutrients. People will avoid any fruit with even a tiny bruise, so peaches and other fruit are picked before they are ripe, still hard, and harder to digest and receive the nutrients (unless you are a ruminant).
People also like sweet food, so modern breeds are loaded with sugar. The article mentioned the new “Peaches ‘n’ Cream” hybrid variety of sweet corn (now the only variety available in most markets) which has high sugar content, but almost zero nutrients. You’d get more nutrients from a Snickers bar.

But the main reason food is less nutritious can be summed up in one word: shelf life. (OK, two words.) Fully ripened, soft, juicy peaches have a shelf life of <two days at room temperature. No store will stock produce that they end up throwing out in two days. Modern breeds of produce are bred for long shelf life, and the easiest way to do this is to breed all the nutrition out of the produce and pick it before it ripens. Nutrients are just as beneficial to germs (bacteria, fungi, mold, insects, &c.) as they are to humans, so the germs thrive on nutritious food, quickly rotting it. Milk and eggs are highly nutritious foods, so they won’t even last a week, even when refrigerated. But California Iceberg Head Lettuce has no nutrition at all, so it will last in the produce bin for a month. That’s why your supermarket stocks it.

Old (heirloom) breeds of fruit have more nutrition and superior flavor. Old varieties of apples such as Russets and King (also called Thompkins King) are wonderful in flavor and crispness, until they spend a week in the grocer’s bin where they quickly dry out.
We don’t get protein from vegetables, Derek. We make our own protein from the amino acids they contain, and as Mr. Glen Oble, my high school biology teacher taught us, amino acids are typically colorful, so food with natural color is generally more nutritious.
But the average customer is reluctant to try a weird-looking fruit or vegetable. The varieties the Times article charted as high in nutrition were purple carrots, purple potatoes, blue corn. Americans would rather buy high-sugar, normal looking food.
The most nutritious and readily available vegetable according to the article? Dandelions! And the old Lebanese immigrants in the neighborhood here can be seen in vacant lots picking them. On a daily walk, I’ll pick a dandelion flower and snack on it — but not the bitter green part: that must be cooked.

A quote from "Principles Of Terrestrial Ecosystems" by F. Stuart Chapin, Pamela A. Matson, Peter M. Vitousek
"CO2 enhancement of photosynthesis also contributes to carbon storage (Norby et al. 2005, Long et al. 2006), although not as much as the short-term CO2 response of photosynthesis might suggest. Over the longer term, CO2 uptake becomes nutrient-limited, as nutrients become sequestered in live and dead organic matter (see Chap. 6; Shaver et al. 1992, Norby et al. 2010). The effect of CO2 fertilization on carbon storage appears to be smaller than that due to reforestation in the temperate zone, but in the tropics, CO2fertilization appears sufficient to offset the loss to deforestation of carbon-fixation capacity (Field et al. 2007)."

As a student of environmental biology, I find that while this video has plenty of good points, it might be a bit misleading in some aspects.
The factors that control the increase in biomass of plants and other primary producer population are those that are the most scarce or limiting in the ecosystem environment. Increasing the resources that are already plentiful in the environment will not have effects on the biomass size increase, because there's only so much that the organism can actually take in. Carbon dioxide is not a limiting factor in terrestrial ecosystems, unlike the aquatic ecosystems, and its increase does not has a considerable increase in plant biomass. Plant growth is most often limited by nutrients such as Nitrogen, Phosphorus etc, so soil nutrient depletion is a bigger danger for leaving us without crops at all, rather than the crops becoming less nutritious.
You don't have to worry about over-eating if you eat lots of fruits and vegetables, because all that soluble fibre will make you feel full. Just be careful about the carbs, especially refined carbs.

I don't think the answer is so simple as just one factor, as a home gardener that grows a lot of vegetables (some crops we are self sufficient in despite living in Sweden and have a short growing season) I've become really interested in getting a good soil and what nutrients I can relay on and if home made nutrients are good and so on.

Saying that farmers take care of their soil by adding nutrients is simply just wrong, traditional farmers use man made synthetic fertilizers often made with just the necessities to make things grow, the soil can't take up a lot of these nutrients and a lot just get washed away because they are water soluble, salts can build up unless they are washed away by rains or watering. Those fertilizers do nothing for soil health worms and other good creatures can't live of this, and without them the soil gets compacted = why farmers need to till the soil but this will kill of even more worms creating this bad cycle where the soil just gets more and more compacted. Plus since they don't add new organic material except those small bits from the last crop that gets tilled down the soil just gets worse and worse. Organic farming is a bit better but it's not as free from chemicals as one would think and some organic fertilizer is not better then conventional when it comes to washing away and not leaving anything for worms and such to live of and they might not add any organic material either so the soil can deplete even there.

In a home garden you can add grass, leaves and other materials to the beds so it can release some nutrients over time but mostly feed worms they will airate the soil bring organic materials deeper and worm poo is really nutrient rich, my own mature older beds that gets constantly improved are super soft to dig in thanks to the worms, the soil is also really heavy because it can hold so much water it's completely different from the soil in the fields surrounding my home where the soil is dense but quite light. I also make my own fertilizers just by pressing down a bunch of weeds in a water barrel and then add some water and let the weeds melt, that way you add back the nutrients from the weeds including vitamins, minerals and ofc NPK aswell so its a better fertilizer than those that add just the essential, but it requires a lot of weeds just to cover a small area and I don't see how it would be possible to scale this up to be doable with how much a farmer would need.

I would really like a comparison study between someone who's beds are made like a hüghelculture or something similar with a lot of organic material, compost and so on compared to organic farming, regular farming and hydroponics. Is there a difference in nutrients, taste and potential yield? You often hear that home grown taste the best is that because its got more nutrients, is allowed to get completely ripened and not just harvested all at once or is it just some biased opinion and placebo effect?

I have cash cropped in Canada for 40+ years. I am one of the few who adds micros based on tissue tests. Organic matter levels in most soils have fallen with time. Excess nitrogen speeds up the process. The OM is a a keystone for the soil microbiome which is essential for soil health. Plants find microbes so essential that they donate 30-70% of their sugar production by excreting it through the roots. If we select for grain yield, we may be stealing from the microbes.
Bigger is not better. Is a 500 lb. obese human a "high yielder'? Nitrogen produces larger plants but the cells are puffed up with water and generally have thinner cell walls. Nutrient density decreases.
It is easy to supplement fertilizer with any essential metals that are shown to be low.

I have been working in Agricultural Research for nearly 10 years, and both from my cropland experience and my close contact with farmers in the corn belt, your statement that "farmers have always put a lot of effort into maintaining their soils" is both painfully wrong and shockingly simplistic consider how good your channel normally is.

Standard fertilizers that ensure maximum crop weight are the bare minimum and economically required. But these fertilizers have nothing to do with the micronutrients this video is concerned with. Topsoil erosion has been mitigated relatively well in my state, but is a major concern in many others. This factor alone objectively results in the loss of critical micronutrients.

Historically and presently, famers don't care anywhere near as much as they should with maintaining their soils. When you work with them firsthand, you see they typically only care that next years crop will be up to spec, and the best of them worry about the land they will be giving to their sons. Beyond that? They couldn't care less if they are losing, say 2% of their soil iron every year. To them, they will never be alive to see it be a concern, their sons likely won't, and as far as they know it will never impact crop profits.

This guy is missing half the logic in the reasoning he's using.
For example:
1. One can easily check whether soil depletion is a factor, by comparing crops grown in brand-new fields to crops grown in old fields. He leaves that out completely.
2. He also says the farmers are careful to fertilize the soil...but he doesn't address the major flaws in HOW they refertilize the soil.
a. that they largely focus on a few major nutrients, like nitrogen. He mentioned mineral decline in food...do farmers even remineralize the soil?
b. And even those who do, is it the same as the naturally occurring minerals? Note that science has recently shown that human beings taking mineral supplements may not be able to actually process and use those minerals like they do when the same minerals are present chemically in food. Perhaps the same is true of some fertilization. Perhaps some or all of the nutrients, because they are chemically a bit different than when they occur in soil otherwise, aren't as accessible.
c. He talks about "still getting big plants", but different nutrient deficiencies may produce different outcomes. Perhaps there is a nutrient problem that doesn't change plant size, only chemical composition.
d. Not only that, but perhaps the plants ARE smaller than they would be without depletion, because having been bred for size, that lesser growth is hidden behind how much larger they now are genetically.
3. He asks about plants not selectively bred, then he skips over the BEST version of this: Heritage/heirloom cultivars. Not only can one find cultivars of plants NOT bred to improve over the past generations, but one can even find old seeds that still germinate, generations later. THAT is the best way to test whether breeding changed things.
4. Honeybees are invasive. So if honeybees focus on native goldenrod as a food source, that would be a harmful breeding influence on the plant.
5. He mentions the dilution effect solely in context of CO2. A money-maker to focus on, but completely unscientific when one considers that the plants are growing at DOUBLE their rates and sizes versus a century ago MAINLY because of the genetic breeding to MAKE them grow faster. If growing 30% more because of CO2 could reduce their nutrient value, how about growing 100% faster because of their genetics?

Oh, and how can he not know how to pronounce "produce"?

While the main point of the video - nutrient loss due to faster growth - is certainly a good point, protein deficiency and satiety are misrepresented here.

1) For many decades protein intake recommendations were way to high. This had multiple reasons: 1. An agenda to promote your own research when your focus was proteins, 2. A growing fitness trend/industry, 3. Meat/Dairy-Lobby - to name a few. With more and more research published nutrionists have decreased and decreased the recommendations. Protein deficiency was never a problem and will certainly be one of the last problems that will arise in the field of nutrition. Instead many people consum to much protein and even get sick.

2) Satiety is a lot more complex than proteins = fullness. Studies have shown that low-protein plant based meals have the same amount of satiety/fullness than high-protein animal based meals, with high-protein plant based ones even higher. Fiber intake, volume, energy density, variety and certainly obesity all have strong effects on both satiety and fullness (And thats only the tip of the iceberg).

Plant nutrients ARE decreasing due to farming practices. Farmers do NOT put a lot of effort into adding nutrients back into the crops with fertilizers. Some probably do, but most do not as it would be way too expensive and they would not make a profit. Fertilizers are a huge expense in farming. (I grew up on a farm and still live in a farming community). The fertilizers added only cover a small few key nutrients (nitrogen, phosphorous, and potassium are the ONLY nutrients added to most crops). This helps the plant to grow big and fast, but causes it to become less nutrient dense (less vitamin C for example) and more susceptible to disease and pests. Thus, increasing the need for pesticides, which when ingested, causes our bodies to use more nutrients to neutralize the toxins. The faster a plant grows (which Co2 and fertilizers cause) the fewer nutrients and anti-oxidants it will produce as it is using all of it's energy to grow, but not to maintain health. So it is likely a combination of increased Co2 and the fertilizers added.

I think you're focusing on protein too much. Protein deficiency is pretty much starvation, which has much more to do with calorie deficiency than nutrient deficiency. A standard plant based diet has plenty of protein for most humans in a first world country, meeting standard calorie requirements. The message of this video might scare first world country citizens into thinking they aren't getting enough protein when in fact most people are eating much more protein than needed in these scenarios. It seems obvious that the plant to animal calorie conversion of ~1:16 in the US is not sustainable and we should be eating way more plants than animals.

I wonder how big of an impact the increase in CO2 actually has. According to his little chart, between 1850 and 2014, CO2 increased from 280 to 400. However, in that same amount of time I bet concentration of vegetation in farmland has increased even more. Meaning that there are more, bigger, plants competing for the CO2. Especially as that high concentration of vegetation has existed consistently in that same area for multiple seasons, making the air less CO2 rich over time. So high demand creates a supply deficit while demand remains constant. There’s also less CO2 producers on farmland. Animals are kept away from crops, and because all the land is covered with crops, there’s less CO2 producing technology as well. Keep in mind that CO2 producing urban areas tend to be pretty far away from rural farmland. So even if CO2 levels increase globally (as there’s less CO2 consumption over the ocean than on land, meanwhile all the CO2 production is in coastal cities) they could still decrease locally.

This would also work well with the anecdotal evidence that people living on farms tend to be healthier, which could be explained in part by the disproportionately high Oxygen and low CO2.

Another theory to this decrease in nutrients and more specifically protein is that the pesticides used by the farming industry, with the main ingredient being Glyphosate, are destroying what's known as the shikimate pathway.  The Shikimate Pathway is a process in which plants, bacteria, and fungi synthesize the 9 essential Amino acids using enzymes. These amino acids are used to build a large majority of the proteins humans need and they cant be synthesized in animal cells. It's estimated that around 4.5 billion pounds of Glyphosate are sold worldwide each year causing around 75% of the air and water to be contaminated. If you want more specifics watch the After Skool video "Chemical Farming & The Loss Of Human Health." They have sources/studies for the information provided. I am not an expert in any way I'm just sharing information thanks for reading.

On your point that we farmers "take care of the soil". We havent. We've been taking care of our cashcrops.

Artificial fertilizers don't feed the soil like manure and compost would. NO3 is watersoluble and will either be absorbed into the plant or get washed away/vaporize. This is why soil-depletion is happening because the soil-food web is circumvented, and so it dies out. Essentially the "circle of life" in agricultural topsoil isnt working properly. We only provide macronutrients through fertilizers like potassium, nitrogen, phosphorous etc, but plants have a long list of dietary needs that arent being supplemented by (most) farmers (iron, sulfur, boron, silica etc.). You actually dont even need to deplete the soil-reserves for this to matter. Nutrient imbalance is enough for the plant to get stressed, say if you have too big Sulfur-Nitrogen ratio.

Controlling CO2 levels in greenhouses is much easier than in open-air farms. As we naturally transition toward hydroponics and greenhouse use, I'd expect to see CO2 level control being a standard procedure. More CO2 = sweeter (I'd assume, due to increased carb ppm), higher yield crops vs low CO2 = higher protein & vitamin density. Crops like potatoes & corn that are grown with a focus on yield over nutrition would probably benefit from high CO2, while crops specifically sought after for their nutrition value like soy beans and broccoli would benefit more from a low CO2 environment

I would like to see a study comparing the nutritional values of crops grown using what we now call "Conventional Farming Practices" and crops grown using "Regenerative Farming Practices."

The place where we are losing nutrients are in our animal foods. The key place this loss is seen is in "amino acids". There are nine essential amino acids, and the primary, most reliable source for those essential amino acids is animal foods. This means that without those amino acids being obtained through food, our bodies cannot, and will not be able to obtain them or create them in any other way. If you look at the effects of what the essential amino acids do for the body, but then invert their effects, you will end up with a list of symptoms that you would find in "autoimmune diseases".

Example: How many people below the age of thirty have arthritis (which is an autoimmune disease)? How many of those people also have another corresponding, more severe autoimmune disease? Arthritis is very common among people with other autoimmune diseases. Based on what I stated before, there must be an inverse to arthritis among the list of the essential amino acids. That answer is Methionine, the only sulfur based essential amino acid. And it specifically is used by the body for joint health, and for joint lubrication, among other uses.

But you can probably notice that this should not seem to be a problem. But a few facts have not been stated yet. Did you know that amino acids are destroyed when they are frozen? Simply by freezing amino acids you nearly destroy all of their nutritional value. So here are the questions you should ask...

When did the freezer become a common household appliance? Then compare that to when the term "autoimmune disease" was classified due to its increasingly noticeable presence. When did we start processing our milk, rather than delivering fresh, raw milk? And was there a noticeable increase in autoimmune disease cases, and types around that time? When did the farming industry start feeding chickens plant foods only instead of their natural diet of bugs? And was there a noticeable increase in autoimmune disease around that time? When a fad called "veganism" started becoming popular, was there a corresponding increase in autoimmune disease in children?

If you do not ask the correct question, you will not find the needed answer. I just gave you the questions, will you accept the answers you find?

A couple of half truths here, but overall no straight misinformation. You make the argument that if there would be a nutrient deficiency in the soil, the plants wouldn't grow to their appropriate size, which is not entirely true. Deficient growth can still achieve the same mass, so you can still have the same yield, but it would look different, and would probably taste like crap.

The reason why plants exposed to more CO2 put on more carbs is because CO2 is the most easily accessible carbon source for plant metabolism, it's a major contributor to growth rate, so anything the plant can use to put on more mass will consist of more, simple carbon structures that are easier/faster to build than anything else, so carbs, while nitrogen, a core building block of protein, takes a back seat.

Protein satiates more than carbs or fat, but I don't think it would be accurate to say we feel satiated when we reach a certain protein target... you just need to eat less of it than fat or carbs (in relative calorie values), to make you feel full. Correlation is not causation. At the same time fat prolongs the feeling of being full for example, so satiation, again, is not just about protein.

Derek - not a timely comment, but I just found your EXCELLENT channel recently.

As an avid horticulturalist, I was already thinking of the headlines over a recent rice study - "CO2 increases yields but DESTROYS NUTRITION" (here, vitamins) - and my SMH response to it. I actually took the data from that study and converted it to Vitamin Content as percent of weight to a PER HECTARE basis, and found yes, BOTH overall (weight) yields AND the vitamins in question increased per unit area.

As you astutely point out, it's RELATIVELY more carbs - "more more" of those, but still MORE nutrients of other sorts, like vitamins. The "more is better, and it's both" message is drowned out by attitudes toward CO2 that are, shall we say, strong enough to bury any fair assessment of cost/BENEFIT in a sea of "yeah, but" framing. Ugh.

I'll have to go back to studies to do protein, but I expect a similar result. If there's one thing about your series that really stands out, it's the respect for truth and scientific rigor that I appreciate most.

Your presentations are precisely the kind of factual, LEVEL-HEADED analyses needed to counteract "pop" alarmism over every stinkin' thing under the sun (IMO, eh) ... so kudos. And thanks.

This whole video is based on the faulty premise that soil depletion is not taking place, ignoring the aspect of soil biology altogether. It thereby implies that large-scale conventional agricultural practices, which rely heavily on synthetic fertilizer and copious cocktails of biocides/pesticides/herbicides, are managing soil well and not contributing to that depletion. The fact is, topsoil around the world is disappearing, turning into lifeless dust. The reasons for that are complex and multitudinous, but current industrial agriculture practices, including the over-use of industrial biocides and fertilizer, are contributing to that. To skip over that point is disingenuous. Furthermore, nutrient content in produce doesn't exactly drive the market, nor does flavor exactly, appearance and ship-ability do, along with price, and thus producers and buyers will naturally select for and concentrate on those traits at the expense of others.

The Greening of Planet Earth
is a half-hour-long video produced by the coal industry, which argues that rising CO2 levels will be beneficial to agriculture, and that policies intending to reduce CO2 levels are therefore misguided.
The video argues that rising CO2 levels both directly stimulate plant growth and, as a result of their warming properties, cause winter temperatures to rise, thereby indirectly stimulating plant growth.
It was produced in 1991 and released the following year.
A sequel, entitled, The Greening of Planet Earth Continues, was released in 1998.
The video was narrated by Sherwood Idso. After the video was made, it was distributed to thousands of journalists by a coal industry group.
The video became very popular viewing in the George H. W. Bush White House and elsewhere in Washington, where it was promoted before the 1992 Earth Summit, and, according to some reports, became especially popular with then-chief of staff John H. Sununu.

Funding for the video was provided by the Western Fuels Association, which paid $250,000 to produce it. It was produced by the Greening Earth Society, which was created by the Western Fuels Association and with which the Association shared a business address.

It's very important to know who funds and makes these documentaries.

Studies done by dr Weston A price done studies on societies that still used wood as their primary fuel source and only ate their native foods. He done these experiments in over 5different countries or places and all these populations that done this and lived the old way had high bone density and had minerals like calcium, magnesium, phosphorus, the fat soluble vitamins at much higher concentrations, in some people they had 20x the amount of calcium we have. Their bone structure and dental structure were very strong and perfect without any cavities and no health problems. The reason why they had so much nutrients was because wood was their primary fuel source. After the wood finished burning all was left was the wood ash and that wood ash although a lot of potassium is a very concentrated mineral source. They would Chuck the ashes outside into the soil thus giving the soil heavy minerals and thus going into their food. Another reason for less minerals is dams. Before dams the rivers and waters would flood onto the crop fields and the rivers carried minerals from other places. After we damed up all the rivers the soil couldn’t get access to these minerals anymore. We know this is true as even in England people used to fight for the land near the waters as it was the most fertile land and crops around the Nile river used to produce large nutrient dense melons and other foods.

I have watched a couple of Veritasium videos lately, and I thought they were pretty good.  But, this video is making me think again about the quality of the information (is this fellow a CO2 nut?).  LET ME PRESENT THE REAL PLANT SCIENCE!  First, plants are very dependent on bacteria and fungi and other micro organisms in the soil.  For example, fungi that surround a plants roots increase what the roots do by 10 to 1000 times.  The bacteria and fungi do most of the heavy lifting for the plant, as they are very adept at sourcing the minerals that the plant needs to grow properly.  Plants produce sugars from photosynthesis (CO2 is needed for this).  A substantial amount of the sugars that plants produce go to feed the bacteria and fungi in the root zone;  sometimes up to 30 percent of the total sugar the plant produces.  Some plants can even change the kind of sugar they produce to feed a different kind of fungi if the plant senses it needs to.  (YES!  The DNA coding in plants is unbelievable!)  With modern farming they use a tremendous amount of man-made fertilizers to feed the plants.  These fertilizers make the plant grow well, but they also kill off the bacteria, fungi, and other micro-organisms in the soil and kill or drive out the earthworms.  You end up with soil that is sterile and needs even more fertilizers to produce the same amount of food.  Read Jeff Lowenfels book on all this, "Teaming With Microbes."  The bacteria and fungi are far more adept at getting the proper minerals for plant growth than the roots themselves are.  And if they ain't there then you end up with plants that look good but lack the nutritional value, and a lot of the taste in food comes from the minerals being there to begin with.  Commercial fertilizers are all in salt form.  Salts bind water to themselves.  Bacterial and fungi require water, and if the fertilizers are binding up the water then they are killed out.  The turning of soil into hardpan is a big problem now days all across the country, as farmers are destroying the soil due to their practices.  It ain't CO2 folks!  Maybe Al Gore or some other goon has paid for the making of this video.  CO2 is PLANT FOOD, and is used to make microbe food.  Commercial growers of cannabis indoors often use CO2 generators to up the CO2 levels from 400 ppm to 1200 to 1500 ppm because the limiting factor in photosynthesis is usually the amount of CO2 that is available.  If there is enough light in the correct spectrums and enough water then you get bigger, stronger, and healthier plants by upping the CO2 and stronger ganja in the end.  Young man, next time you make a video PLEASE do your homework and quite spreading the kind of BS you did in this video.

Mycorrhizal fungi in the soil harvest minerals and nutrients for plants in exchange for sugar. Chemical fertilizers, in particular soluble Phosphorus, break the symbiotic relationship between plants and fungi so that minerals become unavailable and plants are unable to optimize protein synthesis. Wheat crops grown in a symbiotic relationship with fungi have higher protein and mineral levels. A study in Western Australia is showing this to be true.

You are wrong sir, farmers have not, in general, been replacing the nutrients drawn from the soil. Adding nitrogen, potassium and sodium, the main ingredients of commercial fertilizer, doesn't begin to maintain a healthy soil over decades of use. I remember back in the 1960s old farmers claiming they could not raise as many hogs on a acre of corn as they once had, even with hybrid varieties. In 1975 a professor of agronomy at University of Wisconsin told his class it was cheaper and more efficient to dump their dairy manure into a river and use commercial NPK fertilizer instead. That was the heart of the soil he wanted dumped in the river. The chairman of the agronomy department also had such antediluvian ideas, notably , "We never should have banned DDT." It would be wrong as well to assume that any great progress has been made since those days, there hasn't been and won't be any as long as a few mega-corporations controls our entire agricultural system from top to bottom. We aren't breeding nutrition out of our food, we are draining the source of nutrition out of our soils. I'm sorry Vertasium, I'm a subscriber, but I'm afraid you don't know enough about agriculture to be able to see past the glittering surface of things. Albert Howard, for instance, demonstrated meticulously and irrefutably that impoverished soils lead to impoverished crops and the distressed health of animals grown off those crops. His ideas are not considered au courant by big agribusiness.

Hello! I really love this channel and I really appreciate the work of knowledge spreading that you people do. So I wanted to add my humble opinion (as a permaculture and natural agriculture learner) about the arguments that you used in this video. I think this is a very complex topic and this video was way too short and limited. I don't want to make a scientific essay here about the topic, it's just a simplistic opinion comment based on the information, books, articles and experience that I accumulated on the study of Agriculture, in order to expand a bit the view about it. (Sorry for my English orthography and grammar mistakes :):


1. "They're ensuring that soil gets enough fertilizers and nutrients" That exactly one of the main problems about food production nowadays and that's why even big industry is going back to ecological and natural processes based' fertilization. It's not the same that you put 20 grams of pure Nitrogen in the soil than letting agents of nature get 20 grams of nitrogen from the atmosphere, because in this natural way there is a huge number of parallel processes taking place and producing secondary products that goes to different metabolic ways all around the plant and inside the plant. This vision of agriculture was a big failure of glorifying the little knowledge of chemistry that we had one hundred years ago, that saw agriculture as "making a soup", you just add those ingredients and then you have a beautiful vegetable soup. But nature doesn't work like that, and has been proven that this vision took our soil to decay dramatically, all the microfauna disappeared with it, plants are more vulnerable to plagues and natural elements (wind, water flows, etc), also the soil's capacity of holding water falls, etc etc etc .
In the "Wicked Problems" theory (Rittel & Webber) expose that a big thing to keep in mind when we face nature problems is that any solution to a "wicked problem" will bring unexpected consequences, so we should stay in the "heuristics of fear" (If applying some new tech or knowledge can bring negative consequences better let keep going further in the study before applying it).



2. This could sound conspiracy, but unfortunately science is lot of times pollute by market and money interest. Agriculture and Cattle Raising are two of the biggest industries in this planet, and so they are very pollute by money interest, which blocks the advance of learning in the field. Is not like I'm saying that there is a big powerfull head making horrible plans about what you can learn or not, my point of view is that this big head is more ignorant or trapped in the established system than evil, it's more that people fall into believing and maintaining the habits of humans that thought them how to do agriculture, because it's a hard thing to change the way of thinking and to accept that a lot of knowledge that you already learned is wrong. Also we fall in the "lock in" effect, so it's hard to change a system that is so implemented already.



3. That plants are big and look green and healthy don't necessary means that they're productive and healthy. Sometimes this actually comes because human fertilizers produce that the plant spends more energy on growing leafs than it needs, and so metabolism gets altered. Fukuoka demonstrated, with his natural agriculture system, that his plants of rice which had smaller leafs than big convencional agriculture producers' rice plants, were, however, much more efficient in rice production, using absolutely no external products no tilling, no machinery, and relying on crops rotation, compost, etc...


4. About selective breeding, I'm agree. Also with GMO there is the problem that we look to improve one side of the plant but we don't realize that this will change the other side. Is like when psychiatrist thought that to solve depression you just take off this part of the brain without realizing that you are probably affecting hundreds of other functions from the brain


5. Cattle Rising I would say is the biggest problem of food industry. Let say it more clear; Meat is a problem. I'm not vegan and it's not a preferences discussion. It's obvious and proven that cattle rising (in the way we do it nowadays, due to the tremendous demand) is one of the biggest problems we have both for the environment and for humankind (if we can even separate those two).

I don't want to make a scientific essay here, so as a resume; you take 10 thousand cows, put them in a little room, they don't develop right, they get weak, they don't develop their muscles and systems, they get sick, you give them antibiotics, they produce metan, they feel fear and depression (which has been proven that they do feel it), viruses mutate (hello A-flu, Influenza, and probably Covid-19), and well in conclusion you have a very sad, poorly nutritious, medicated and polluting peace of meat that if you eat everyday will increase your chance to suffer various kinds of cancer and heart diseases.


6. Also there is a problem about fertilizers, plaguicides, fungicides, and the infinite list of products that farmers think they need for some strange reason that I still don't understand as a natural farmer learner. They not only destroys the ecosystem around, but also most of times contains substances that are not digestible both for human body and animal os plants bodies, and so they accumulate and produce various diseases.


7. About the CO2 factor, that's something I had no idea about, and I think it's really interesting. Just want point, plants need CO2 to develop but that doesn't mean that they are able to consume and infinite quantity of it as sometimes I heard. It can cause overdose in the same way that water can cause hyperhidratation and can even kill you.

It would be interesting to see a scientific comparison of today's modern hybridized wheat (before it is enriched) with ancient grains such as spelt.

A similar situation exists with corn. It's been hybridized and/or modified to produce yield, at the expense of nutrition.

There are plenty of experiments going on and have been done on how the change in CO2 concentration changes plant grows. Here's the TL:DW. Nutrients in soil are finite, and plants are still pulling out the same amount, but either due to our agricultural practices of maximizing crop yields, or though increased CO2 levels which increase plant growth, those same quantity of nutrients are spread out over a larger crop. This in effect makes it seem like there's nutrient depletion if you compare crops by weight over time. Weight and calorie density increases, but nutrient levels per plot of land remain static.

There is one more element you should consider, which is the fact that our agriculture and many of our occidental practices conduced to an important destruction of biomass. In soil, il species which feeded on those in soil, but also in the whole wild biosphere. And that this destruction of biomass means degradation which ultimately leads to liberating CO2. So, my point if that the CO2 rising my be in a large part due to this and not only to fossil energies.

This means that greening the planet should not only be considered on the nutrient side, but also as a corrective step set by the ecosystem "in order" to restore this destroyed biomass and any political action intended to reduce carbon, might have as a consequence to hinder this restorative process.

By the way, researchers a Lydia and Claude Bourguignon suggested that another reason why plants are less nutritious, might be that they are intoxicated by the amount of chemicals we pout in the earth, and that they absorb much water in order to dilute this concentration. I don't know if this makes sense.

Dude... did you just skip over soil depletion and fertilization by saying 'they still grow big, so can't be a problem?!?!'   - The difference between looking after soil using compost, fallow crops and charcoal vs. modern chemical fertilizers is a massive deal, how could you just skip that?  In a nutshell, there is supposed to be a healthy living ecosystem in soil and its also supposed to have trace amounts of almost all elements in it. Over time plants absorb these trace minerals and then we eat them and absorb them. However, if we don't use proper soil maintenance techniques, and instead we use modern fertilizers, then for the most part we are only replacing the nitrogen, phosphorous and potassium in the soil. These are essential ingredients for plant growth, and allow plants to grow big. However, over time, by never replacing the other minerals and elements in the soil, the soil becomes depleted. This is why we need mineral supplements and multivitamins today - because we no longer get them in our food. Thus, you have neglected a major factor in plant nutrition without even acknowledging it properly.     That said, genetic manipulation, artificial fertilizers and increased CO2 do all contribute to larger plants with lower nutrient concentrations, so thank you for pointing that out. However, do please inform people about the great importance of healthy topsoil. Its been a huge part of our history, as cultures who don't respect topsoil usually suffer the consequences. Check out "Topsoil and Civilization. By Tom Dale and Vernon Gill Carter." for more info.

I have never found a flaw in your science, however the soil science expertise is very shallow here! I am not an expert, but have had many conversations and sat in on a few soil science classes of an expert...so , I will make a few points. The soils in the central sections  of North America we’re laid down over millennia of abundant wildlife fertilizing and tilling (via hooves and burrowing etc...) , not the least of which were million strong bison herds, along with seasonal flooding that produced results similar to the Nile region. Also, good soil must have uninhibited micro organisms to produce some of the missing components. All the artificial and very limited array of replacements placed on the top soils in the last century don’t even come close to the complexities they seek to replace. Add to that all the anti-microbial products dumped in vast quantities, we have at best a weak imitation of soil and at worst a dying and thinning top soil.

CO2 concentration and soil depletion are mutually connected. More CO2 in the atmosphere causes acidic rains, which change the pH of the soil. Even if farmers are careful enough and they enrich their soil with microelements (iron, zinc) as well as your standard NPK (Nitrogen, Phosphorous, Pottasium) fertilizers, plants can only absorb certain nutrients if the pH of the soil is the correct amount (usually a pH of around 7 ensures that all elements are absorbed sufficiently). If the pH deviates from that value, the plant's won't be able to absorb all of the nutrients that they require.

" ... untouched by selective breeding ..." -- somewhere around 3m20s... along the same line of reasoning that we now refer to "global warming" as "human induced climate change", there's no evidence to suggest that bees aren't organised enough to selectively breed. Consider this: when bees are foraging for food, they're likely going to go to the best source of food first, thus cross-pollinating the plants the very same way we do when we want to selectively breed (except we do it with tiny paintbrushes, and they do it with their faces). They are, by the very nature of life which is to seek the best nutrients and thus chance of continual life, selectively breeding the very crops that they visit, and perhaps without even realising it.

Thus, though we can reasonably discount human-enduced selective breeding with regards to that weed, I don't think we should discount bee-induced selective breeding here... Rather than focusing on what's causing the vitamin deficiency, I think you should focus on where the vitamins are going... you know, matter cannot be created nor destroyed, we live in a world where the fittest survive longer and so forth... is it possible that the nutrients are ending up caught in other parts of the cycle of life that we compete with? For example, we won't touch the majority of mushroom species, yet they are highly competitive... is it possible that we're losing protein, for example, to the more poisonous species of fungi?

I see that Cody is into bees... perhaps he might have some input here... in any case, I can see proof of selection by the ants in my back yard; they're putting aphids on some plants and ignoring others... hmmmmmmmm...

I'm a gardener and it's definitely not the same to use non-organic soil nutrients as we do now for the greatest part than to use organic ones like compost. Plants mostly grow on CO2 from the air, water and three chemical nutrients from the soil: potasium, phosphorum and nitrogen. But while that is most of the picture, it's surely not all, and just as a free range chicken doesn't taste at all like an industrial "prisoner" chicken (and surely does not have the same nutrients either), industrialized agriculture is probably depleting the soils in terms of micronutrients that were more abundant when farming was done the traditional way. Also chemicals and irrigation seem to add up to soil depletion. Believing that our modern intensive agricultural practices are not without cost, just because farmers supposedly do their best to keep the soil nutritious, is a dangerous non-scientific idea, bordering pseudoscience. After all, it cannot be the same when farms employed actual humans and cattle than now, when farms are basically machinery and farmers only exert some supervision over huge farm lots they can't possibly have an intense communion with.

The keyword is "soil food web".
Mono-culture decreases the diversity in soil food web. Which leads to depletion from over harvesting/mining the same nutrient from the soil. Synthetic fertilizer only adds few nutrients but generally those few that make plant grow faster but not providing enough for the depleting nutrient.

- Nitrogen (N): leaf growth
- Phosphorus (P): Development of roots, flowers, seeds, fruit
- Potassium (K): Strong stem growth, movement of water in plants, promotion of flowering and fruiting

Plants need these but not only these.

The check and balance of good soil is done by mycorrhizza fungi, the internet of plants. endomycorrhizza fungi sticks into the roots of most plants. Mycorrhizza fungi will trade/exchange and mine nutrients from the soil for the plant we consume and for itself. Kill mycorrhizza fungi and you get factory plants, plants with high NPK and carbon and lack everything else. In most mono-culture sites, mycorrhizza fungi level is extremely low. The soil food web is therefore broken/weak.

I grew up on a farm, and honestly I think the selective breeding theory is at least part of the problem. My area has a lot of apples, and one of the most iconic apple types is Red Delicious. It’s the one that’s super dark red and has that really uniform apple shape, and it tastes like cardboard. Occasionally you’ll get one that tastes like slightly sweet cardboard. That’s not at all what Red Delicious apples tasted like even 50 years ago. They used to taste good, but companies decided to breed for color, shape, and durability instead of flavor because that’s what people bought. And this is continuing to happen. Farms need to breed for certain things to even be able to break even, and the cost of that is taste, and sometimes ripeness. That’s why stuff you buy in a grocery store doesn’t taste as good. It could tie into this too. There’s no way to maintain a farm using old breeds that may have better nutritional value, and keep cost of food/cost of living low. If we want better quality food, it’ll cost more, and more and more people can’t afford that.

This video is astonishingly and uncharacteristically lacking in skepticism. The core thesis is illogical. Dilution effects by definition have zero negative impact on human nutrition. To see why, start by considering inputs (water, labor, pesticides, etc.) fixed. A doubling of CO2 increases yields (dry mass) without increasing (or decreasing!) net protein and vitamin content. That means for the same price, poor people (i.e. those at risk of nutrient deficiency) get the same amount of vitamins and protein as they would have without the dilution effect. They just get more calories from carbs. Which is a good thing, if you're at risk for starvation!

All the more reason that we should seriously be looking into mass scale regenerative agriculture. People like Gabe Brown have proven on thousands of acres to be able to systemically increase soil carbon by half a percent a year. 1% to 1.5% to 2% to 2.5% to 3% to 3.5% and so on.

Another wonderful example is Allan Savory in Africa who has learned how to properly manage cattle and literally turn desert back into carbon sequestering grassland. The major difference being that if cattle are loose stock to an unmanaged they will destroy the land and turn it into desert but if they are mob stock rotationally grazed they will turn desert back into grassland.

They're also happens to be quite a few other factors in the nutrient reduction of our food that you failed to mention. A couple examples of which are: The chemical chelation effect of glyphosate. The systemic destruction of the soil life (bacteria and fungi) which is necessary for plants to be able to digest the minerals trapped in double and triple bonds in the sand, silt, clay and rocks from which all plants have gotten their nutrients since plants came into existence. You are dismissing soils way to easily. Carbon content in soils have fallen sharply. The soil food web has changed because of this. Mycorrhizza fungi builds soil carbon because it needs it to buffer water, as the fungi needs a certain moisture level to thrive.

Most plants associate with this type of fungi, and trade minerals and water with them for carbohydrates and some protein.

Please learn more about the soil food web, and you will understand that while atmospheric carbon and plant genetics both are important, they are not the answer alone. Nature is complex, so reductionistic thinking can only get you so far. To find real answers, systems thinking is needed. A good place to start is to learn to differentiate between complicated and complex systems.

As a gardener (and going to study horticulture next year), I find all this very convincing. Making a plant put on more mass quickly is exactly what you expect from a CO2 rich atmosphere (and it's even done as a fertilizer in sealed greenhouses), but giving plants an "unbalanced diet" tends to lead to deficiency symptoms. With a small increase in CO2, getting a slight boost in sugar, starch, and celulose production would not make the relative deficiency in other plant components notable.
Everything considered, not seeing a decrease in relative nutrition ratios after an increase of CO2 in the air would be somewhat puzzling.

And in the same last 200 years infant mortality rates have dropped (rapidly in the Developed World, and slowly in the Developing World), and life expectancy rates have risen.
Poor nutrition conditions like rickets have been eradicated in the West, and there's much improvement in the Developing World.
In general we are becoming bigger & stronger, though arguably not fitter due to our sedentary lifestyles.
Obesity, though a 'huge' problem, should be easy to address - the solution is the same as it ever was - exercise more & eat less (and make better decisions about what happened do eat). Humanity should be able to overcome these problems if we think creatively, plan effectively & follow through with these plans .
It isn't all bad news - if we do something about it then it's just news.
